should any previous helper text be displayed again.

Choose the right prefix or suffix
A prefix or suffix can be displayed if the content is presented with that information in
other contexts. In the Input Field, it lets users know that they don't need to type in the
prefix or suffix. Some examples include fields for values in specific currencies, weights,
and distances in specific units.

Decide whether your field is optional or required
By default, all fields are treated as required. If a field is inessential yet still needs to be
displayed, it should be labeled accordingly by adding “(optional)” to the end of the label.
Mobile number (optional)
Data format
If a user's data should be formatted any particular way, the desired format should be
displayed by the helper text and, if possible, the input should automatically format the
data once the user focuses on another field.
While focused, the Input Field should accept data in any format. When unfocused, if the
formatting is different than expected, the value should be reformatted. When
reformatting, the input should be as flexible as possible, but if the value cannot fit into
the expected format the input should change to an error state. The desired formatting
needs to be defined on a case-by-case basis along with the implementation of the
method that will be triggered once the focus moves to another element.
To prevent the user from going beyond the formatting constraints the input should also
have a character limit, but that limit should take into account the different ways
someone can enter the requested data. For instance, a user could enter a phone
number as “(000) 000-0000" or “0000000000” and both would be correct, but the first
method has a different amount of characters than the second.
